profileText: A Representative from Indiana; born on a farm in Hamilton County, near Noblesville, Ind., January 18, 1918; attended Hamilton County schools; graduated from Butler University, Indianapolis, Ind., in 1941; served in the United States Army from November 18, 1941, to August 12, 1944, as a demolition specialist for the Ordnance Department in Middle Eastern, North African, and Italian Campaigns; farmer; partner in livestock commission company; National Commander of Veterans of Foreign Wars in 1957-1958; chairman of Indiana Veterans Commission, 1954-1960; elected as a Republican to the Eighty-seventh and to the four succeeding Congresses (January 3, 1961-January 3, 1971); was not a candidate in 1970 for reelection but was an unsuccessful candidate for election to the United States Senate; administrator of Veterans Affairs, Veterans Administration, 1971-1977; died January 28, 1995.

researchRecord.name: 1965-1976, 25 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Richard L. Roudebush contain chiefly papers and correspondence from the 90th Congress, including legislative files on agriculture, air traffic safety, the Indiana Dunes National Lakeshore, civil rights measures, defense spending, crime, flood control, air pollution, Job Corps, and veterans benefits. Subjects documented include issues before Congress, the seating of Adam Clayton Powell, the nomination of Abe Fortas as Chief Justice, the Vietnam War, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, lowering the voting age, and the House Un-American Activities Committee. Other materials consist of papers on the Republican National Committee and the 1968 Republican National Convention, 1968 campaign files, financial and administrative records, condolence letters to families of soldiers who died in Vietnam, constituent correspondence from the 91st Congress, and speeches as an official of the Veterans Administration. A finding aid is available in the repository.
